review_blob:
On tap near Atlanta.
Slightly hazy light copper body with a good head and excellent lacing.
Moderately strong aroma features citrus tinged hops, with at least as much oranges as grapefruit. 

The flavor is more earthy and a little less appealing.  Moderate complexity for style. 

Medium body with crisp carbonation that seems a bit too high.

On tap at T-Mac.
Clear copper body topped by a durable head. Good lacing.
Paired with a grapefruit IPA from Red Brick. The Virginia IPA was similar but a touch more bitter, less complex, and with more grapefruit and grapefruit peel flavor. Stronger aroma too. I did miss the orange notes present in the milder beer from Red Brick.
Medium body.
beer_name: Starr Hill The Hook Grapefruit Session IPA

review_blob:
12 oz can with a BB date stamp on the bottom of 15 July 2016. Served in a lager glass. 

A- deep amber body with an off-white head that has good retention. Decent lacing.

Aroma: tropical fruits, particularly mango and pineapple, dominate some faint light grain scents. 

T- good mango flavor with hint of green apples, other tropical fruits, and light hops. Enough hop bitterness for bitter/sweet balance. 

M- medium body with medium, soft carbonation.

Overall: crisp, tropical and refreshing; a fine brew for the summer.

12 oz bottle into a Belgian snifter. 

Look: opaque, essentially black body topped by a thin and weak medium brown head. Limited lacing. 

Aroma: Complex and appealing with less obvious alcohol than usual for 10.4% Hints of dark fruits, vanilla, and toffee.

Flavor: Dark chocolate, vanilla and faint coffee and aged wood flavors. Some dark fruit flavors with a touch of cherry. Excellent bitter/sweet balance. 

Mouthfeel: Creamy smooth. Very full bodied. Alcohol warmth but its not hot or harsh. 

Overall: excellent.

12 oz bottle with a BB date stamp of 29 Aug. 2016, poured into a lager glass.  

A: Fairly clear cherry/rose body topped with a thin white head that dissipates quickly but leaves some lacing.

Aroma: a nice light cherry dominates.

Taste - tart cherries and moderate saltiness; hints of lemon and baked bread. 

Feel - lightly puckering tartness; light bodied; medium-light carbonation.

Overall - well done

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob:
Pour from a 12 oz, screw top, bottle. 

Crystal clear pale golden body with a moderate size white head that has god legs. Lots of visible carbonation. Good lacing.

Aroma: lightly funky and fruity; moderately yeasty. 

Taste: light grain up front immediately followed by soft fruit notes and a tartness that builds into the finish. Touches of bitter and earthy notes in the aftertaste appear under the tart fruit. .

Feel: dry; very light bodied; medium+ carbonation. Refreshing.

12 oz bottle with no visible date, served in a Belgian snifter. 

Appearance: It has a small, weak, light brown head over a nearly black body. Little lacing.

Aroma: Strong, appealing aroma of roasted peanuts. Hints of dark fruits and black bread.

Taste: lots of roasted peanut flavor, with some nuances. Dark roasted malts come out in the finish and aftertaste. 

Mouthfeel: semi-smooth, medium body; light-medium carbonation. 

Overall: a very good peanut butter porter with a particularly fine aroma and a robust flavor.

330 ml bottle served in a St. Bernardus snifter. BB date of 28 Jan. 2017. 

Hazy mahogany body with a thin, weak head. Patches of lacing left on the glass nonetheless. 

Aroma: Some barnyard and wet leather aromas mixed with dark over-ripe fruits. 

Flavor: moderately tart with a light sweetness. Less funky and more, appealing dark dried fruit and cherries than the aroma suggests. 

Overall: not my favorite Rodenbach.

Large 750 ml shared bottle.
A slightly funky tripel with enough barrel aging to have as much impact as the base beer. Lots of yeast and bourbon notes.
Recommended.
beer_name: Lickinghole Creek Three Chopt Tripel (Bourbon Barrel)

review_blob:
12 oz bottle.

Loads of coffee in the nose. Plenty in the flavor too, but not so much as to mask some dark bread notes from the malts.
Medium full body with medium carbonation.

Shared bottle.

Very fruity and surprisingly strong aroma. The flavor follows with generous hopping but only mild to moderate bitterness. 

Light-medium body and medium carbonation.

Shared bottle with a January 2016 bottling date.

Flavor: Hint of marshmallows, vanilla and dark chocolate. The chocolate builds in the aftertaste. Lightly sweet all the way to the finish where it turns slightly bitter.

Excellent feel. 

Overall: well done.

Shared bottle.
OK looking.
Smells fruity but otherwise funky and repelling.
The flavor is WAY better and only mildly funky. Moderate tartness and other strong flavors cover some funk.
Good mouthfeel.

Shared bomber bottle.
Generous white head over a hazy golden body.
Tart fruity funky aroma.
Better taste with only mild funk.
High tartness and plenty (too much?) of sea salt.
Overall: tart!!

Shared bomber bottle.
Mildly fruity and very funky aroma partially carries over to the fruity and moderately funky flavor. Salt level not too high. Medium body and carbonation.

Overall wild gose; too funky for me.

A bourbon barrel aged "sour stout" from a very fresh growler.

Looks like a stout, smells like a hybrid, tastes mainly like a sour. Moderately high tartness. Quite fruity with a suggestion of cherries. Long lasting sour fruit aftertaste. Mild bourbon barrel effects.

From 12 oz bottle with no date stamp. Served in a lager glass.

Appearance: clear ruby-brown body with lots of visible carbonation. Large, fluffy beige head and decent lacing. 

Smell: Sour and baked grains. Faint spices. 

Taste: sweet, medium and dark roasted malts with faint spicy hops and a suggestion of smoke. Nice roasty aftertaste with plenty of chocolate fades too quickly. 

Mouthfeel: medium+ body with medium carbonation. 

Overall: Worth trying but its no Founders or Fullers.

Poured from 12 oz bottle with a BB date stamp of 11 July 2016. Served in a lager glass.

Appearance: medium amber body with lots of visible carbonation. Decent head and lacing. 

Smell: floral/fruity/herbal hop notes with bready malts. 

Taste: the hops are dominant but theres an underlying bready malt component and fairly mild bitterness. Single hop but multi-dimensional hop flavor. 

Mouthfeel: medium body with crisp, medium+ carbonation; very dry finish

Overall: a distinct, dry pale ale. Certainly worth trying .. and buying again.
beer_name: Green Flash Pacific Gem Single Hop Pale Ale

review_blob:
12 oz bottle, date stamped BB 10-Sept.-2016, served in a lager glass. 

Pours with a clear, medium amber body that has a some fine-grained visible carbonation. Decent head and lacing. 

Aroma: about equal contributions from malts and hops. 

Flavor: this is a slightly sweet and malty version of the style. Nicely clean and very easy drinking. 

Overall: very nice, and recommended, version of the style.

12 oz bottle served in a lager glass. "Brewed and bottled by Shmaltz Brewing".

Well, here I am in upstate SC -- hard to believe Im entering the first review for an IPA from Brooklyn. 

The amber-copper body is clear even though theres some sediment on the bottom of the bottle. The body is topped by a durable off-white head. 

Theres a surprising sweet note when this hits the tongue, but hoppy bitterness builds into the finish to levels expected of an IPA; at least an English IPA. The hop mix is quite different (and better) than expected from the UK, however: The hops favor fruity notes with fainter floral notes. 

Feel: medium body with lively but soft carbonation.

12oz bottle, bottled on 2/232/16,.poured intolager glass. 

Pours copper in color with a subtle haze; fluffy light tan head that slowly fades and leaves stick, patterned lacing. 

Aroma: peppers, subtle apricot, and faint caramel malts. 

Flavor: better and more balanced than the aroma indicates. Excellent balance between the apricots and chilies, with neither so strong as to completely mask the malts. 

Mouthfeel: medium-bodied with moderate carbonation. Mild chili heat that works well. 

Overall: Part fruit beer, part amber ale, part chili beer: despite what the aroma suggests, the apricots and chilies blend very well together. Worth seeking out if you like spicy beers.

330 ml green bottle with a cryptic production stamp. Served in a lager glass. 

A: Clear amber with a moderate size head that fades to a durable white top coat.

Smell: Euro hops dominate; faint bready malts

Taste: Better than the aroma suggests with more malt, especially up front. Mild+ bitterness. 

M: Medium but softer (natural?) carbonation than usual for style (in bottles). 

Overall: a decent Czech style pilsner.

12 oz bottle of "Huger Street IPA" with 7.2% ABV; 58 IBUs. 

Pours with a slightly hazy copper body topped by a large, durable, off-white head. Lots of lacing is left on the glass. 

Both the aroma and the flavor are light for style, although the flavor builds some with repeated sipping. Fruity and herbal hops dominate the aroma but the hops are nearly balanced by malts upon tasting. 

Feel: medium body and good, medium carbonation. 

Overall: well balanced, easy drinking IPA that some will find too lightly hopped.

12 oz can into a lager glass. 

A: Pours a deep amber-apricot color with moderate amounts of visible carbonation rising to a moderate size white head. The head is durable and plenty of sticky lacing is left on the glass. 

Aroma: Surprisingly strong aromas of fresh mango with hints of tropical fruits and bread.

Taste: Fruity and lightly sweet up front. Theres increasing fruitiness afterwards, but the light sweetness is quickly replaced by a citrus/grapefruit bitterness from the hops that momentarily builds to a moderate level.

Feel: Medium-light bodied; moderate amount of carbonation; fine dry and clean finish. 

Overall: an excellent session IPA (or APA); with a great mix of mango and citrusy hops, notably low ABV, and plenty of flavor, this is one of the best of style.

14 month old 500 ml bottle served in a Porter Bar goblet.

Appearance: Russet-mahogany colored body with a thin but semi-durable light beige head. Spotty lacing.

Smell: Spicy roasted grains and dark bread with roasted peppers. Hints of chilies and chocolate. 

Flavor: Follows the aroma to a point, but the chilies are more apparent, particularly after some heat builds with repeated sipping. Strong, complex spicy flavor; even stronger than the aroma suggests. 

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Lively, medium carbonation.

Overall: unique and interesting, with moderate chili heat.

On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops.
Large foamy durable head.
Medium-light body.
Light aroma with biscuits, grassy notes and hints of citrus fruits.
Flavor follows.

Overall: clean, rather unremarkable.

On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops.
Listed as "Special Zero Mile" at 7.7% ABV (label on keg). 
Decent foamy and bubbly head.
Medium-light body.

Strong hoppy aroma suggesting weed.

Flavor is milder, less bitter (mild), and much less weedy/hoppy than the aroma suggests. 

Overall: clean, interesting and fun to drink.

On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops.
Large foamy durable head.
Light body.
Light aroma with biscuits, and hints of citrus fruits.
Flavor follows. Leans towards bold and hoppy for style.

Overall: clean, rather unremarkable, light pils.
beer_name: Southern Tier One Buffalo Our Beer

review_blob:
On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops.
Durable white head over a hazy golden body. 
Medium-light body.
As promised, a rather hoppy aroma with biscuits and hints of citrus fruits. Flavor follows.

Overall: clean, hoppy wheat beer.

On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops.

Near black, opaque body that looks thick and is topped by a short head thats not very durable.

Thick, viscous full body with appropriate light carbonation.

Excellent aroma with admirable complexity. Dark bread, dark dried fruits and vanilla. 

Flavor is disappointing after this great aroma. It lacks balance, has strong sweet and bitter notes that dont counterbalance, is too boozy, and has too much char.

Overall: OK for style.

On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops.

Decent head over a black body. Medium body.

Aroma: sweet toffee with dark bread.

Flavor follows. Too boozy, especially for less than 7% ABV.

Overall: very good but not excellent nor particularly memorable.

On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops. (Review done ignoring one tap that seemed to be a soured batch.)

Off-white head over a brown--amber body. Medium body and carbonation.

Rich aroma with adequate hops and more malts than expected for style.

Flavor follows although more hops than the aroma suggests.

Overall: decent Brown IPA.

On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops.

Clear amber body. Medium carbonation and body.

Aroma: typical, with tropical fruit notes from the hops.

Flavor follows.very good sweet-bitter balance.

Overall: clean, easy drinking IPA.

On tap at 2016 Hogs and Hops.

Bubbly, semi-durable head.

Medium-light body and near medium carbonation.

Aroma of bread and banana. 

Flavor follows the aroma and carries more spicing (yeast). 

Overall: nice version of this style.

12 oz 2015 bottle with a BB date stamp of 27 July 2016, served in a Porter Bar goblet. 

Appearance: dark but clear mahogany body topped by a disappointing, fizzy head that quickly fizzles out leaving just a minimal partial coat and minimal lacing.

Aroma: cocoa, faint cinnamon, and dark toast.

Flavor: similar to the aroma but more cinnamon and less cocoa. Good bitter/sweet balance. 

Feel: near medium body with well hidden alcohol and lively,artificial carbonation. .
beer_name: Monday Night Drafty Kilt Cinnamon Cocoa

review_blob:
12 oz can. 

Appearance: Hazy golden-apricot color, with a thin, weal head. 

Aroma: herbal and light citrus hopping with bready malts. 

Taste: More fruity and less malty than the nose. Citrus, apple and pineapple notes dominate. 

Feel: light with moderate to high carbonation

Overall:this session IPA, like many others of this ilk, drinks and tastes like an APA. This version has an attractive and distinct hop mix producing a nice hint of pineapple.

12 oz 2015 bottle allowed to warm for about 25 minutes then served in a Porter Bar goblet. 

Aroma: complex mix of various dark dried fruits, fruitcake, and hints of toffee.

Flavor: similar to the aroma; good complexity and balance. Sweet for style, leaning a bit towards a barleywine. 

Feel: full and smooth but with more alcohol heat than optimal. Light but appropriate carbonation. 

Overall: excellent; clearly I ought to get more and age it a while.

can into a lager glass. 

Appearance - Amber colored body with a tall white head that soon dies down to a thin but durable top coat; Nice patterned lacing is left sticking to the glass. Moderate visible carbonation. 

Aroma - Wheat bread and lot of apricot jam.

Taste - Apricot start to finish. Various vague soft ripe fruit and bready notes interweave. 

Feel - Medium carbonation; Semi-dry finish. 

Overall: worth a try if you enjoy apricots or fruity wheat beer.

12 oz can with more appealing graphics than seen earlier on bottles. Served at about 50F in a lager glass. 

Brown-ruby body with excellent clarity and an above average dark beige head. Sticky patches of lacing are left behind after a full sheet slides back into the body. 

Aroma: markedly hoppy for style.
Flavor: malt dominated but by a thin margin with more spicy hops than usual for style. Excellent balance. 

Overall: a very nice sessionable red ale with added interest from spicy hops and an excellent appearance and mouthfeel.

12 oz bottle; bottled on 28 Dec. 2015. 

Faint dark malts, sweet chocolate and vegetative aromas with more prominent raspberry aroma.

Flavor: Quite a bit of raspberry and chocolate but not so much as to be objectionable or to entirely mask the dark malts. The level of raspberry clearly exceeds the other components. Still some faint vegetative notes but better than the aroma suggests. Mildly sweet bitter-sweet mix.

12 oz 2015 bottle into a lager glass. 

Pours with a nice looking, reddish-orange body topped by an decent head. Limited lacing. 

Feel: sharp, lightly biting when it hits the tongue, but mellows afterwards. Mild acidity. Medium+ body and carbonation. 

Aroma: Fruity and tart, with hints of lemon, green apple and cherry.

Flavor: quite tar with pleasant notes of soft ripe fruits including tart cherries. Some biscuit too. Clean and not funky for style.

12 oz bottle with a BB date of May 2016 served in a snifter. 

Cloudy light apricot-colored body topped by a durable head that leaves sheets of lacing. 

Aroma: Fruity and grassy elements stick out in a complex mix. 

Flavor: grapefruit hop notes, but mild bitterness with more tartness and some sweetness. Peppery, yeasty and hoppy finish. 

Feel: Medium+, soft carbonation in near medium body; semi-dry finish.
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - Tank 7 Farmhouse Ale

review_blob:
12 oz. bottle. 5% Cellared but past BB date; ratings compensated partially.
Slightly hazy amber body with a decent head.

Flavor: Wheat, spicy hops and bread.

Medium body and carbonation.

12 oz can at the Spring 2016 ASMF. 5.8%

Pours clear dark red brown, looking near opaque in the glass. Decent head.

Simple but appealing aroma dominated by dark roasted grains. Hints of hops and chocolate. Theres more than a hint of hops in the flavor, aging a fine level of spiciness to the dark grains. Excellent level of (mild) bitterness.

Near full body with rather lively carbonation.

Overall: I think this is a good upgrade to the earlier FCB Chocolate Stout.

12 oz can from the NC brewery taproom.
25 November 2015 canning date.
Near opaque dark brown body with a very good head. Good coffee flavor with good intensity such that the dark malts show too and bring some dark chocolate to the mix. Nicely balanced mix continues into the lingering aftertaste. 

Full creamy mouthful after the initially too strong carbonation dies down.

12 oz can.
Pours hazy apricot topped with a generous, foamy off-white head.
Typical fruity and spicy aroma with banana and clove.
Light, lively body.

Overall: mainstream and decent version of the style.

22 oz 2013 bottle at 2016 ASMF.

Strongly flavored with enough coffee, dark grains or hops to completely overpower the others in most beers. In this fine brew, however, they coexist in good balance. 
Even after over 2 years, this is still a little boozy, but this works well for this strongly flavored brew. The coffee strength is surely lower than when fresh but is still the last thing to fade from the long lasting aftertaste.

Overall: with the base beer a favorite, this coffee-added version should be a winner and it doesnt disappoint.

Shared crowler at ASMF.
West Coast style DIPA with a fruity and floral aroma.
Smooth body with a bit off hop bite from the extravagant hop load.
Strong floral hop flavor in the aftertaste.

Shared crowler from Pennsylvania.
Great looking IPL. Lots of visible carbonation rising to a massive and durable head.
fruity and point aroma suggests a heavy hop load, although the hop character turns more earthy and herbal than fruity. This is just what the flavor delivers. More hoppy than any IPL Ive tried, and most IPAs too.
beer_name: St. Boniface Offering #25: India Pale Lager

review_blob:
12 oz bottle into a Belgian snifter. BB date stamp: 17 Sept. 2016. 

Clear orange-amber body topped by a decent head. 
Aroma: fruity hops and some alcohol esters.
Flavor: as described by the brewery (see above) with a touch of honey.  
Feel: medium body and near medium carbonation.
